content.webTitle: On my radar: Nicolas Godin’s cultural highlights

fields.headline: On my radar: Nicolas Godin’s cultural highlights
fields.bodyText: Born in Paris in 1969, Nicolas Godin studied architecture at the École Nationale Supérieure d’Architecture de Versailles, where he met Jean-Benoît Dunckel. They formed the electronic music duo Air, releasing their debut album Moon Safari in 1998. Five more studio albums and two soundtracks followed, including a film score for The Virgin Suicides in 1999. Godin released his first solo album, Contrepoint, in 2015; his second, Concrete and Glass, is out on 24 January 2020 on Because Music. 1. Design Charlotte Perriand: Inventing a New World Architecture is a big part of my life: my dad was an architect, and I studied architecture before I started making music. Charlotte Perriand worked and made iconic designs with Le Corbusier. She designed simple things for everyday life – tables, stools, kitchens – so you can find her design in a lot of places. There’s a minimalism to her work, but also a playfulness, a lightness. I think this exhibition [at the Louis Vuitton Foundation in Paris] is very important, because she was a bit underrated compared with people like Jean Prouvé, but now she’s getting the praise she always deserved. 2. Nonfiction The Age of Surveillance Capitalism by Shoshana Zuboff Jaron Lanier’s Ten Arguments for Deleting Your Social Media Accounts Right Now introduced me to the new business model of data and Google and so on. So I dug into all these newspaper and magazine articles, then last weekend I started reading this book. I have to say that it was quite scary, because it details all these new forms of economy that don’t follow rules of any kind. I think everybody should be aware of what’s happening and this book is very good for that: it’s clear and well written and well explained, and it allows you to form your own opinion. 3. Television Watchmen (HBO) There are so many TV shows now but this one is unique: I just finished watching it and it’s very smart. I like it when shows are commercial – in that they are successful and people watch them – but at the same time very weird. This one has a lot of strange flashbacks and strange philosophies, but it’s approachable for everybody. I thought the music was really cool, then I saw on the credits that it’s by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, who I’m a big fan of. It’s an amazing soundtrack: it takes possession of you. 4. Music book Phoenix: Liberté, Égalité, Phoenix! (Rizzoli) I love this book for many reasons. I’m part of that movement from the 90s when all these French bands showed up on the scene, so it’s like an old group of friends I’m happy to see 20 years later. Usually books about bands are more like fan books, but this one is a real piece of art. It shows all aspects of life in a band, and how you can achieve a career without losing your essence. They really put their soul into the publishing of it: the way it’s presented, the photographs. It really is a classic. 5. Shop Workshop Issé, Paris This is the best sake shop in Paris. My friend Christian and I go here all the time to test new sake and eat food – in France we’re obsessed with pairing the right drink with the right food. It’s my headquarters: every week I go there and buy new products from Japan, and I do all my groceries there – you can find everything you need to cook Japanese food. I love the design, I love the music and I love their philosophy. This little shop is very important for me. I need that kind of place in Paris. It’s like my drug. 6. Place Anavilhanas national park, Brazil My wife is from Brazil so we go there all the time, and it’s really scary what’s happening right now with the Amazon fires and all that destruction. I encourage anyone to go to this reserve: it’s a natural archipelago three hours from Manaus, where you can discover the Amazon ecosystem by boat. You feel the wilderness of the environment and all the animals – it’s very noisy at night – and you can feel you’re part of something way, way bigger than you. You have to take a couple of planes to get to the lodge, but once you’re there you will not regret it.
